GPyOpt.core.bo module¶

class GPyOpt.core.bo.BO(acquisition_func, bounds=None, model_optimize_interval=None, model_optimize_restarts=None, model_data_init=None, normalize=None, verbosity=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

change_to_sparseGP(num_inducing)[source]¶

Changes standard GP estimation to sparse GP estimation

param num__inducing:
 number of inducing points for sparse-GP modeling
change_to_standardGP()[source]¶

Changes sparse GP estimation to standard GP estimation

continue_optimization(max_iter, verbose=True)[source]¶

Continues Bayesian Optimization for a number H of iterations. Requires prior initialization with self.start_optimization

Parameters:
  • max_iter – new exploration horizon, or number of extra iterations
  • verbose – show messages
plot_acquisition(filename=None)[source]¶
Plots the model and the acquisition function.
if self.input_dim = 1: Plots data, mean and variance in one plot and the acquisition function in another plot if self.input_dim = 2: as before but it separates the mean and variance of the model in two different plots
Parameters:filename – name of the file where the plot is saved
plot_convergence(filename=None)[source]¶
Makes three plots to evaluate the convergence of the model
plot 1: Iterations vs. distance between consecutive selected x’s plot 2: Iterations vs. the mean of the current model in the selected sample. plot 3: Iterations vs. the variance of the current model in the selected sample.
Parameters:filename – name of the file where the plot is saved
start_optimization(max_iter=25, n_inbatch=1, acqu_optimize_method='random', batch_method='predictive', acqu_optimize_restarts=10, stop_criteria=1e-16, n_procs=1, verbose=True)[source]¶

Starts Bayesian Optimization for a number H of iterations (after the initial exploration data)

Parameters:
  • max_iter – exploration horizon, or number of iterations :param n_inbatch: number of samples to collect in each batch (one by default)
  • acqu_optimize_method –
    method to optimize the acquisition function
    -‘brute’: uses a uniform lattice with ‘acqu_optimize_restarts’ points per dimension. A local CG gradient is run the best point. -‘random’: takes the best of ‘acqu_optimize_restarts’ local random optimizers.

    -‘fast_brute’: -‘fast_random’:

  • nb – number of samples to collect in each batch (one by default) :param batch_method: method to collect samples in batches -‘predictive’: uses the predicted mean in the selected sample to update the acquisition function. -‘mp’: used a penalization of the acquisition function to based on exclusion zones. -‘random’: collects the element of the batch randomly -‘sm’: simulating matching methods.
  • acqu_optimize_restarts – numbers of random restarts in the optimization of the acquisition function, default = 10.
  • stop_criteria – minimum distance between two consecutive x’s to keep running the model
  • n_procs – The number of processes used for evaluating the given function f

..Note : X and Y can be None. In this case Nrandom*model_dimension data are uniformly generated to initialize the model.

GPyOpt.core.optimization module¶

GPyOpt.core.optimization.estimate_L(model, bounds)[source]¶

Estimate the Lipschitz constant of f by taking maximizing the norm of the expectation of the gradient of f.

GPyOpt.core.optimization.estimate_Min(model, bounds)[source]¶

Takes the estimated minimum as the minimum value in the sample

GPyOpt.core.optimization.fast_acquisition_optimization(acquisition, d_acquisition, bounds, acqu_optimize_restarts, model, method_type, X_batch=None, L=None, Min=None)[source]¶

Optimizes the acquisition function using a local optimizer in the best point

GPyOpt.core.optimization.full_acquisition_optimization(acquisition, d_acquisition, bounds, acqu_optimize_restarts, model, method_type, X_batch=None, L=None, Min=None)[source]¶

Optimizes the acquisition function by taking the best of a number of local optimizers

GPyOpt.core.optimization.hammer_function(x, x0, r_x0, s_x0)[source]¶

Creates the function to define the exclusion zones

GPyOpt.core.optimization.hammer_function_precompute(x0, L, Min, model)[source]¶
GPyOpt.core.optimization.mp_batch_optimization(acquisition, d_acquisition, bounds, acqu_optimize_restarts, acqu_optimize_method, model, n_inbatch)[source]¶

Computes batch optimization using by acquisition penalization using Lipschitz inference.

Parameters:
  • acquisition – acquisition function in which the batch selection is based
  • bounds – the box constrains of the optimization
  • restarts – the number of restarts in the optimization of the surrogate
  • method – the method to optimize the acquisition function
  • model – the GP model based on the current samples
  • n_inbatch – the number of samples to collect
GPyOpt.core.optimization.optimize_acquisition(acquisition, d_acquisition, bounds, acqu_optimize_restarts, acqu_optimize_method, model, X_batch=None, L=None, Min=None)[source]¶

Optimization of the acquisition function

GPyOpt.core.optimization.penalized_acquisition(x, acquisition, bounds, model, X_batch, r_x0, s_x0)[source]¶

Creates a penalized acquisition function using ‘hammer’ functions around the points collected in the batch

GPyOpt.core.optimization.predictive_batch_optimization(acqu_name, acquisition_par, acquisition, d_acquisition, bounds, acqu_optimize_restarts, acqu_optimize_method, model, n_inbatch)[source]¶

Computes batch optimization using the predictive mean to obtain new batch elements

Parameters:
  • acquisition – acquisition function in which the batch selection is based
  • bounds – the box constrains of the optimization
  • restarts – the number of restarts in the optimization of the surrogate
  • method – the method to optimize the acquisition function
  • model – the GP model based on the current samples
  • n_inbatch – the number of samples to collect
GPyOpt.core.optimization.random_batch_optimization(acquisition, d_acquisition, bounds, acqu_optimize_restarts, acqu_optimize_method, model, n_inbatch)[source]¶

Computes the batch optimization taking random samples (only for comparative purposes)
